text: lo this is chef john from food wishes
calm web roasted rack of lamb with
strawberry mint sauce that's right
welcome to my latest experiment for new
things to do with Easter lamb and this
time I decide to try sauce featuring
everybody's favorite spring fruit
strawberries no they're not just for
dessert anymore and of course like most
edible experiments in the kitchen there
may be one or two things we do
differently next time but nothing too
major and we'll get to that but all now
for a first-time attempt I was very
happy with how this came out so let's go
ahead and get started with 1 pound of
beautiful ripe hopefully sweet
strawberries which I've already rinsed
off in cold water and what we'll do to
prep these besides obviously cutting off
the green thing from the top and I
believe the proper term for that is
hulling in case you're into terms but
anyway besides cutting off the top what
we'll do is cut these in half or
quarters depending on the size so for
the big ones we'll cut them twice into
quarters or if they're a little smaller
you can just cut them in half so we will
work our way through those strawberries
cutting them as shown before adding the
rest of the ingredients to what is
hopefully going to be a sauce that
straddles that line between sweet and
savory so with that in mind let's go
ahead and add some freshly grated lemon
zest as well as some freshly squeezed
juice from the exact same lemons and I'm
only showing me adding the juice from
one lemon but I did actually end up
adding a little more later so as usual
you're going to go by the ingredient
amounts I give on the blog post and not
necessarily what you see here and then
to balance that acidity plus the
tartness from the berries we will also
squeeze in some honey and then let's go
ahead and finish off this new recipe
with two of the world's oldest
ingredients which are nice big pinch of
salt as well as a splash of water and
what we're going to do is place this on
medium-high heat and bring it up to a
simmer and just a little heads-up that
there's not going to be a lot that
happens too first couple minutes but
you'll see is that mixture heats through
those strawberries will start to give up
their liquid and they will soften and
they will break down and once that
starts to happen what I like to do is
back the heat down to medium-low and
simply continue cooking stirring
occasionally until those berries are
completely broke it down and extremely
soft and if everything's gone according
to plan your mixture should look
something like this then what we'll do
once that's been accomplished is turn
off the heat and pass this mixture
through a fine mesh strainer and as I
say every time the step is always
optional but the theory here for doing
it is that all that beautiful strawberry
goodness kind of goes through the screen
leaving behind the less delicious seeds
and fibrous bits and you're probably
thinking is that the part that's good
for you yes but here nobody cares do not
confuse this with some weeknight kal
salad okay this is a sauce for like
Easter Sunday or some other momentous
occasion so we're not really going to
worry about that so I just keep stirring
and pressing with the spatula until one
of two things happens all that pure
strawberry goodness has been passed
through or I get tired to strain in it
and hopefully those happen in about the
same time and then once that mixture has
been strained I will give it a little
taste and add more seasoning if I think
it's necessary which I did so I added
some more salts as well as a little
shake of cayenne just to stay in shape
and is another reminder that the sauce
should have a good amount of savoriness
to it and we will stir that in and then
what we want to do is let this cool down
to room temperature before finishing it
and by finishing it I mean add the
freshly sliced mint as well as of course
one final check for seasoning and the
reason we let this cool down first as I
was hoping that would help them it
retain that fresh flavor as well as
bright gorgeous color but unfortunately
only one of those things happened even
though the taste was good as this sat
those pieces of mint got really dark so
I think what we'll do next time is add
that right before we're going to serve
it so not a major deal but something we
would want to adjust in the future since
as I like to say that's us cooking and
then once our strawberry and mint sauce
is set we can move on to the rack of
lamb your standard ready to cook eight
bone rack of lamb which is going to be
somewhere between a pound and a half and
a pound and 3/4 and if your butcher
doesn't already sell them like this tell
them you want it fully trimmed they'll
know what you're talking about if not
show them this video and what we're
going to do is roast this on a foil
lined baking sheet but not before
generously season it with kosher salt
freshly ground black pepper and a little
cayenne and by the way it only took me
eight years to figure out if I added
those all together I could save a lot of
time filming this part but anyway we're
going to season that all over at which
point we can place this in the center of
a very hot 475 degree oven
for ten minutes to give it an initial
searing and what I'm showing you here is
an alternative to our usual method for
rack of lamb the difference is I will
explain in full detail on the blog post
but basically with this method we sear
it first before building our crumb crust
which by the way is usually just Dijon
mustard in buttered bread crumbs but in
keeping with the seasonal theme instead
of just using plain mustard I added a
couple tablespoons of finely minced
green onions which if you use them this
time of the year you can legally call
them spring onions and I stirred that in
to hopefully make this a little
extra-special and then besides the
mustard to make them stick we also need
our buttered crumbs which are nothing
more than plain breadcrumbs moistened
with just enough melted butter to make
the mixture look like wet sand and then
besides the breadcrumbs in the butter
one thing you don't want to forget which
I almost did here is to add a nice big
pinch of salt or sometimes I'll use
Parmesan or both but we do want to
season that up and that is it for our
crumb topping so once our rack of lamb
is seared for 10 minutes in that hot
oven we'll spread it with enough of our
mustard green onion mixture excuse me
spring onion mixture to coat the surface
at which point we will sprinkle over and
press on our butter crumbs which is
really easy to do on the flattop
surfaces but for the front of this
you're going to have to use the old
angled hand trick just place your hand
like this while you apply those crumbs
and you should get them to stick to that
edge without much problem and then once
our rack lamb has been carefully
designed and thoughtfully chromed we are
going to reduce our heat down to 375 and
place that back in for about 15 minutes
or so or until the internal temp sabai
125 and that should produce a beautiful
juicy lamb somewhere between medium-rare
and medium and by the way for crumbs
aren't as Brown as you want just turn
the broiler on for a minute which I did
just to give a little extra color and
then once our rack has been properly
roasted we must let it rest at least 10
minutes before slicing if you don't all
our juices are going to run out when we
cut it which could very well lead to
sadness and disappointment so let it sit
for at least 10 minutes before slicing
in and if you haven't done this before
it's pretty easy simply don't cut into
the
own cut between the bones and
theoretically that knife should go right
through now let's go ahead and cut that
piece in half because I'm going to do
two ribs per serving and using this
method in the suggested internal temp
you should be looking at some beautiful
hot juicy pink meat oops wrong side
there we go in fact let's get it close
up so we can see it a little better come
on that looks pretty good and for me
that is the perfect degree of doneness
so we'll go ahead and cut up our lamb
and serve you there two or four chops
over a nice pool of our recently
completed strawberry mint sauce and
again you can see here why we're going
to add the mint right the last second
next time because while that doesn't
look exactly terrible I think it would
look significantly better if those mint
leaves were still bright green but
anyway we'll place down our juicy and
perfectly pink lamb next do some equally
gorgeous baby cauliflower and then I'm
usually not a big garnish with a sprig
of mint guy but here of course that's
totally appropriate and that's it our
roasted rack of spring lamb with
strawberry mint sauce is done and
looking almost absolutely beautiful so
let me go ahead and cut in here and see
how we did and I always feel like I have
to mention once in a while when the
cameras off I actually am pretty good at
eating because that was supposed to turn
crust side up but it didn't that's okay
I still somehow someway got it up to my
mouth and besides he already complained
about color the mint issue for a
first-time experiment I was really happy
with how this came out I mean it's no
news flash that a fruity mint based
sauce would be good with roast lamb but
because strawberries have that kind of
unique tartness to them I thought they
work particularly well here especially
when you bring in the acidity from that
green onion mustard mixture we used to
hold down the bread crumbs I thought it
was just all a beautiful combo and of
course it might be obvious but I'll
mention it anyway even if you're
planning on doing another cut of lamb
like a roast leg of lamb this sauce
still would work great I think but of
course that's up to you you guys are the
Mary's of your little lamb but
regardless of what you actually serve
this with I really do hope you give it a
try soon so head over to food wishes
comm for all the ingredient amounts and
more info as usual and as always
enjoy
